<panel  header="**48. :fas-info-circle: 💡 Testing template code to help make testing easier**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/65" expanded>

I found that cd-ing into the test folder each time to run it is a pain, so I used a SCRIPT_DIR so that you can run it outside of the folder. Feel free to copy and use. 

Though note that this is tested only for runtest.sh and not .bat

```bash
#!/usr/bin/env bash
# Reference: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/59895/how-do-i-get-the-directory-where-a-bash-script-is-located-from-within-the-script
SCRIPT_DIR=$( cd -- "$( dirname -- "$``{``BASH_SOURCE[0]``}``" )" &> /dev/null && pwd )

# create bin directory if it doesn't exist
if [ ! -d "$SCRIPT_DIR/../bin" ]
then
    mkdir $SCRIPT_DIR/../bin
fi

# delete output from previous run
if [ -e "$SCRIPT_DIR/ACTUAL.TXT" ]
then
    rm $SCRIPT_DIR/ACTUAL.TXT
fi

# compile the code into the bin folder, terminates if error occurred
if ! javac -cp $SCRIPT_DIR/../src/main/java -Xlint:none -d $SCRIPT_DIR/../bin $SCRIPT_DIR/../src/main/java/Duke.java
then
    echo "********** BUILD FAILURE **********"
    exit 1
fi

# run the program, feed commands from input.txt file and redirect the output to the ACTUAL.TXT
java -classpath $SCRIPT_DIR/../bin Duke < $SCRIPT_DIR/input.txt > $SCRIPT_DIR/ACTUAL.TXT

# compare the output to the expected output
diff $SCRIPT_DIR/ACTUAL.TXT $SCRIPT_DIR/EXPECTED.TXT
if [ $? -eq 0 ]
then
    echo "Test result: PASSED"
    exit 0
else
    echo "Test result: FAILED"
    exit 1
fi

```
</panel>

<panel  header="**54 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/53#issuecomment-1907024077" expanded>

> Hi @tankh99 , I'm from your senior batch (dropping by in this forum to see if I can help you guys).
> 
> I shall not comment too much on your question while I give your peers a chance to think about it and discuss (you probably can add a `for-Discussion` tag to this issue).
> 
> > I don't really like this syntax because it breaks the purpose of the enum
> 
> Separating the enum from a string _can_ have its benefits.
> 
> Consider this, you are tasked to refactor an existing software to support multiple languages.
> 
> Assuming that the existing software did not use any enum, you would then have to go through the whole source code, find lines which checks for keywords, and add in additional keywords (of the other languages). That is going to be a lot of work (even more soft if the project is big), making the software hard to scale.
> 
> On the contrary, if the existing software used enum instead of string. Then the change is simpler: you just need to find the function that maps the string to enum and add in additional keywords (of the other languages). The change is easy and localized (to one function) hence improving scalability.

thanks for the language analogy, this makes a lot of sense!
</panel>

<panel  header="**100 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/527#issuecomment-2006983223" expanded>


> Yes, recent Java versions added other very Java specific features such as default methods, and the ability to include private methods for internal use within the interface. But in the UML discussion we were focusing on regular interface methods i.e., the abstract methods that makes up the _interface_. Those cannot be private. Making them private would break the concept of an interface, as an interface is something you expose to the outside world, for other classes to implement or rely on. If you want to show those Java-specific private methods in a UML diagram (which is unlikely to be useful, as they are for internal use within the interface), you should show the visibility of all methods so that there is no ambiguity.

> If I understood correctly,
> 
> * it's not true that you should put **a** system as an actor, it is just that you should not put the system that is _the software you're developing itself_ as an actor. If you're developing an API, then "automated scripts interacting with the API" might as well be an actor.
> * the intention is that the things described in use case diagrams describes _high level_ interactions (i.e. one bubble represents a whole use case). So an action like "system notifies user of new messages" would be too granular, since often the next action in the use case would be "user check new messages" or "user discard the notification".

<panel  header="**38. :fas-info-circle: How to design `CommandException`?**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/626" expanded>

Currently, I want to make a common superclass for `CommandExecutionException` (which happens when a command is executed, renamed from `CommandException` in AB3) and `ParseException` (which happens when a command is parsed). The purpose is to make a method `getErroneousCommandPart()` method to be available on them.

Unfortunately, this is impossible because `ParseException` already inherits from `IllegalValueException`, and Java does not allow diamond inheritance. Making it no longer inherit from `IllegalValueException` would break API compatibility, and of course it doesn't make sense to make either `CommandException` or `IllegalValueException` to inherit from the other.

I come up with the following workaround:

* make `CommandException` an interface.
* unfortunately, this does not allow writing `catch(CommandException e)` instead of `catch(ParseException | CommandException e)`, or `public void f() throws CommandException` instead of `public void f() throws ParseException, CommandException` etc.
* furthermore, I cannot provide a private field for `CommandException` like `private final CommandPart erroneousCommandPart;`

So,

* Is this a good workaround?
* Is there any other alternative?
* The problem is that nothing in the interface guarantees that classes inherit it must also inherit `Exception`. Is there a good option for this?
</panel>

(Alternatively, why don't AB3 just use GitHub Actions or something to generate the images automatically? Is it possible?)
</panel>

<panel  header="**44. :fas-info-circle: Should a pull request be merged if it is known it has a bug?**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/598" expanded>

Context: #575.

Suppose the problem is the following:

* a team member takes some task
* sends a pull request
* I point out some bugs in the implementation
* the team member can fix the bug, but will takes a very long time

Is it recommended to **merge the feature anyway, and deal with the bug in a future pull request**?

I think:

* Advantage: Reduce the chance of merge conflict later on.
* Disadvantage: Increases the number of bugs that must be fixed, which would cause problem if not fixed by the strict deadline.

<panel  header="**49. :fas-info-circle: Why are the existing AB3 tests overly indirect?**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/559" expanded>

e.g. one of the test looks like this

```
        Person expectedPerson = new PersonBuilder(BOB).withTags(VALID_TAG_FRIEND).build();

        // whitespace only preamble
        assertParseSuccess(parser, PREAMBLE_WHITESPACE + NAME_DESC_BOB + PHONE_DESC_BOB + EMAIL_DESC_BOB
                + ADDRESS_DESC_BOB + TAG_DESC_FRIEND, new AddCommand(expectedPerson));


        // multiple tags - all accepted
        Person expectedPersonMultipleTags = new PersonBuilder(BOB).withTags(VALID_TAG_FRIEND, VALID_TAG_HUSBAND)
                .build();
        assertParseSuccess(parser,
                NAME_DESC_BOB + PHONE_DESC_BOB + EMAIL_DESC_BOB + ADDRESS_DESC_BOB + TAG_DESC_HUSBAND + TAG_DESC_FRIEND,
                new AddCommand(expectedPersonMultipleTags));
```

where

```
    public static final String NAME_DESC_BOB = " " + PREFIX_NAME + VALID_NAME_BOB;
```

and `PREFIX_NAME` is outright imported from the real code by `import static seedu.address.logic.parser.CliSyntax.PREFIX_NAME;`.

The point of tests is to ensure that the main code does not have bugs. To do that, we want the tests to not have bugs as well.

However, it appears to me that the more complicated-looking the tests are, the more likely they are to have a hidden bug and/or test the wrong thing.
Why don't we directly hard code the string that consists of the test into the test code? That would reduce the probability of accidentally testing the wrong thing.


</panel>

Personally, I automatically interpreted "descendant" as "non-strict descendant" while reading that question based on the context, and did not think too much about it.

I decide to look up the Java specification. https://docs.oracle.com/javase/specs/jls/se17/html/jls-8.html#jls-8.1.4 The formal term used is "subclass" instead of "descendant", and it indeed only consider strict subclass.

> The superclass relationship is the transitive closure of the direct superclass relationship.

and

> A class is said to be a direct subclass of its direct superclass, and a subclass of each of its superclasses.

I suppose both convention is fine. (while C++ uses `operator&lt;` as the canonical comparison operator, in mathematics, a poset uses $≤$ as the canonical comparison operator)

<panel  header="**110 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/649#issuecomment-2035837258" expanded>

First, as you know how git works, the commit history is not linear. Rather, it's a tree-like structure.

`git log` or similar tools, however, list the commits chronologically, so it's normal that the commits appear interleaved.

Usually, `git merge` is intelligent enough to correctly apply the patches. The rest you have to resolve manually. That's just the normal merge conflict resolution process.

You can certainly undo the sync fork feature if it gets too difficult. You can do the following:

* use `git reflog` to find the previous commit id. https://stackoverflow.com/questions/28932515/how-to-unmerge-a-git-merge
* `git reset --hard` to set the branch back to that commit id.

But because it's desirable for you to apply the new change anyway, assume the current tree structure is:

```
  --- B
 /
A
 \
  --- C
```
your branch is C, your friend's branch is B. Then do `git diff A C` to see all the developments you made, `git reset --hard B` to move to the merged upstream/master, then manually reapply the changes.
</panel>

<panel  header="**123 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/830#issuecomment-2058654186" expanded>

Personally I'd say 10001 is "common sense" enough. You **don't** want to spend time in your job typing out 10001 lines for the enum (remember that in Java you have to type out all the enum values and it must reside in the source code), and of course such code won't get approved.

That said, "can take only a small number of finite values" feel like an incorrect explanation. The common sense explanation would be "use enum when the names are meaningful, and use integer when the integer value is meaningful". 

E.g. even if you assume "each person can have at most 3 children", it would not make much sense to create `enum NumberOfChildren ``{`` ZERO, ONE, TWO, THREE ``}``;` since if you want to add one children you need to switch-case it.

In particular, always use enum for nominal types, and don't use enum for interval/ratio types. (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Level_of_measurement)

------

Technically in Python you can dynamically generate an enum with a large number of values. But at the moment I can't think of a valid use case, since `__getattr__` exists anyway.
</panel>

<panel  header="**132 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/906#issuecomment-2067335207" expanded>

Take this example of an observer-observed pair in AB3.

```java
        commandTextField.textProperty().addListener((unused1, unused2, unused3) -&gt; setStyleToDefault());
```

Here, the `CommandBox` is the observer and the `TextField commandTextField` is the observed object. Notice that in order for the observer to work, it need to pass an object implementing a specific interface to [`addListener`](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/javafx/api/javafx/beans/value/ObservableValue.html#addListener-javafx.beans.value.ChangeListener-), specifically the [`ChangeListener` interface](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/javafx/api/javafx/beans/value/ChangeListener.html).
</panel>

<panel  header="**133 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/895#issuecomment-2067346567" expanded>

If I understood correctly,
* it's not true that you should put **a** system as an actor, it is just that you should not put the system that is *the software you're developing itself* as an actor. If you're developing an API, then "automated scripts interacting with the API" might as well be an actor.
* the intention is that the things described in use case diagrams describes *high level* interactions (i.e. one bubble represents a whole use case). So an action like "system notifies user of new messages" would be too granular, since often the next action in the use case would be "user check new messages" or "user discard the notification".
</panel>

<panel  header="**134 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/876#issuecomment-2067352402" expanded>

The "none of the alternative" means: "It is possible to omit the `else` block".

For example, if `a` is an integer, it is possible for an `alt` frame to have `[a==1]` and `[a==2]`, without `[else]`.

In that specific tutorial question however, you're already assuming `forward==!backward`, so if it were to get inside the `opt` box, at least one of the two branch must be executed.
</panel>

one thing to also note is which methods are accessible and which is not, this was not obvious for me at start

```ruby
class A ``{``
    public void foo() ``{``
        System.out.println("foo1");
    ``}``
``}``

class B extends A ``{``
    @Override
    public void foo() ``{``
        System.out.println("foo2");
    ``}``
    
    public void foo2() ``{``
        System.out.println("ok");
    ``}``
``}``



public class Main
``{``
	public static void main(String[] args) ``{``
		A a = new B();
		a.foo(); //prints "foo2" as others explained
		a.foo2(); //Does not run, as at compile time, a is created with type A and hence can only access A's methods and not B's despite new B().
	``}``
``}``
```

<panel  header="**18 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/31#issuecomment-1903586560" expanded>

I was also pretty stumped by the jargon in the question at first, and I had to type out the classes to visualise what the sentence was trying to illustrate.

Suppose you have an is-a relationship between where the Task object is the parent class with the method `execute()`, with its child class having an implementation of `execute()` which overrides the parent's implementation, for example.

``` java
// Task is the type of object seen at compile time
public class Task ``{``
    // ...
    // constructors and attributes omitted for brevity

    // This is the original implementation of execute as seen at compile time, and also the overridden method
    public void execute() ``{``
        System.out.println("Executing task...")
    ``}``
``}``

// Example is the "actual type of object" seen at run time
class Example extends Task ``{``
    // ...
    // constructors and attributes omitted for brevity

    // This is the "implementation in the actual type of object", which is what is resolved to by dynamic binding.
    @Override
    public void execute() ``{``
        System.out.println("Executing task...");
    ``}``
``}``

public static void main(String[] args) ``{``
    Task t = new Example();
    t.execute(); // compiler thinks it prints "Executing task", but actually resolves to execute() in the Example class
``}``
```

Hope I helped!
</panel>

<panel  header="**8. :fas-info-circle: 💡 [TIP] Git patching, a potentially helpful git feature**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/627" expanded>

Context: Someone I know was having issue with getting the tests and build to pass. So how do I "send" them my changes.

Problem: I don't have write access to their repo, neither do I want the commit be under my name. But I want to help them and send them the necessary changes so we can move along. I am familiar with `git stash` so I was wondering if I can "send my stash" to them.

Turns out you can!

Basically it turns the $\Delta$ (diff) between the repo in 2 different point in time (between commits, stashes etc), and git can then use this $\Delta$ to apply the changes.  
  
1. Checkout their repo / branch / whatever
2. Make your changes
3. This part can vary but for simplicity I just use `git stash` to store the changes in a stack.
4. Turn it into a patch file by `git stash show -p`
  1. On Linux / Unix / MacOS: `git stash show -p > note-fix.patch`
  2. On windows (careful of Encoding issues): `git stash show -p | Set-content -Encoding utf8 note-fix.patch`
5. Send the patch file to them
6. They see the stats with `git apply --stat note-fix.patch` (basically shows the diff in a normal git status)
7. Confirm? Apply with `git apply note-fix.patch`
8. Push!


Credits:
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/2160638/how-can-i-format-patch-with-what-i-stash-away
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/72607580/error-when-trying-to-apply-git-diff-no-valid-patches-in-input
https://www.gitkraken.com/learn/git/git-patch

Apparently this is the ancestor of a pull request

Appendix:
```
PS C:\Users\ruibi\Documents\Random Projects\tp forks\tp> git stash show -p | Set-content -Encoding utf8 note-fix.patch
PS C:\Users\ruibi\Documents\Random Projects\tp forks\tp> git apply --stat note-fix.patch

 .../address/logic/parser/AddCommandParser.java     |    4 ++--
 src/main/java/seedu/address/ui/ClientCard.java     |    5 ++---
 src/main/resources/view/ClientListCard.fxml        |    2 ++
 .../duplicateClientAddressBook.json                |    2 ++

 .../java/seedu/address/logic/LogicManagerTest.java |    3 ++-
 .../address/logic/parser/AddCommandParserTest.java |    4 +++-
 8 files changed, 23 insertions(+), 10 deletions(-)

PS C:\Users\ruibi\Documents\Random Projects\tp forks\tp> get-content .\note-fix.patch
diff --git a/src/main/java/seedu/address/logic/commands/AddCommand.java b/src/main/java/seedu/address/logic/commands/AddCommand.java
index a80e2cfc..0e31a5d9 100644

<panel  header="**12. :fas-info-circle: Changing Parser in tP to use Apache Commons CLI Library**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/509" expanded>

## Library

[Apache Commons CLI](https://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-cli/)

## Purpose

We want to explore potentially using this library to replace the parser in tP because the input format `p/(phone_number``}``` is not very verbose compared to CLI standards people are normally used to like `--phone ``{``phone number``}```. We also think it might be easier for development, abstraction. 

It is currently a hypothetical thought process, can we specify in NFR like parser library must be third party for example?

The Apache Commons CLI library provides an API for parsing command line options passed to programs. It's also able to print help messages detailing the options available for a command line tool.

Commons CLI supports different types of options:

- POSIX like options, for example `tar -zxvf foo.tar.gz`
- GNU like long options, for example `du --human-readable --max-depth=1`
- Java like properties, for example `java -Djava.awt.headless=true -Djava.net.useSystemProxies=true Foo`
- Short options with value attached, for example `gcc -O2 foo.c`
- long options with single hyphen, for example `ant -projecthelp`

A typical help message displayed by Commons CLI looks like this:

```
usage: ls
 -A,--almost-all          do not list implied . and ..
 -a,--all                 do not hide entries starting with .
 -B,--ignore-backups      do not list implied entried ending with ~
 -b,--escape              print octal escapes for nongraphic characters
    --block-size <SIZE>   use SIZE-byte blocks
 -c                       with -lt: sort by, and show, ctime (time of last
                          modification of file status information) with
                          -l:show ctime and sort by name otherwise: sort
                          by ctime
 -C                       list entries by columns
```     

## License

[Apache 2.0 License](https://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0)

Git repo: https://github.com/apache/commons-cli?tab=readme-ov-file

</panel>

<panel  header="**21. :fas-info-circle: 💡How to understand tagging**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/36" expanded>

After getting confused by what exactly tagging is, heres a simple foolproof-way to doing tagging for iP.  
  
A tag is basically a **bookmark**, it points to a specific commit.  
  
**Add the tag after committing**.   
  
So for example:  
```bash
# this is the commit that implements Level-1
git commit -m "``{``commit message``}``"
git tag -a Level-1 -m "``{``Message or comment for the tag, e.g. Implement Rename, Greet, Exit``}``"

# renaming a commit BEFORE PUSHING
git commit --amend

git push 
git push --tags # this uplaods the tags to GitHub
```

  
A commit can have multiple **tags** but a **tag** can only point to one commit.

Hope this help those who are lost with what are tags exactly.  

You also tag retrospectively, after you have already committed.  
https://git-scm.com/book/en/v2/Git-Basics-Tagging#_tagging_later

Checking your tags
---
There is a command to see the associated tag.  
  
`git show level-1`
will show you the what commit level-1 is tagged to:

```
ip> git show level-1
tag Level-1
Tagger: [Snipped]
Date:   Mon Jan 22 18:00:00 2024 +0800

Echo and bye function

commit 85e9b72e761065[snipped] (tag: Level-1)
Author: [snipped] <>
Date:   Mon Jan 22 18:00:00 2024 +0800

    Level-1 Set up echo function

```

</panel>

Good point! Exceptions for control flows is something from _CS2030S_ (PTSD lol) and I don't think handling __edge cases__ is that bad of a "pattern".

My take away:

The most basic jobs can probably be automated, some of the more humans orientated stuff is probably here to stay, finding user stories (not writing but discovering what the user actually wants), working with stakeholders and etc. The best way is to have a conceptual understanding of what you are doing, you are the architect, AI can be the builders. A: Product design is hard, and achieving a very good design takes experience, skill, and multiple iterative refinements. Hence, having some feature flaws at this stage is natural. Accordingly, feature flaws will not be penalized In the following cases:

<panel  header="**11. :fas-info-circle: Which code is a better application of SLAP?**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/593" expanded>

Out of the two classes below, which is better?

```
class A ``{``
    void doStuff() ``{``
        // ...
    ``}``

    void doMoreStuff() ``{``
        // ...
    ``}``

    void doSomething(boolean b) ``{``
        doStuff();
        if (b) ``{``
            doMoreStuff();
        ``}``
    ``}``
``}``
```
```
class B ``{``
    void doStuff() ``{``
        // ...
    ``}``

    void doMoreStuffIfB(boolean b) ``{``
        if (b) ``{``
           // ...
        ``}``
    ``}``

    void doSomething(boolean b) ``{``
        doStuff();
        doMoreStuffIfB(b);
    ``}``
``}``
```

Initially, class `B` seems to be a better option as `doSomething()` only has 1 layer of abstraction. However, on closer analysis, `doMoreStuffIfB()` is more restrictive than `doMoreStuff()`, which could potentially be used by another method with a different condition. Any thoughts?
</panel>

<panel  header="**22 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/101#issuecomment-1913277755" expanded>

Looking at your commit history, you merged from the master branch into branch-Level-7 instead of the other way. However, this merge did not do anything as the master branch was unmodified since the branch was created.

Hence, you need to merge branch-Level-7 into master and override the incorrect tag by passing -f into git tag:
```
git checkout master
git merge --no-ff branch-Level-7
git tag Level-7 -f
git push origin master
git push -f origin Level-7
```
Edit: You also need to force-push the new tag to override the remote tag.
</panel>

<panel  header="**23 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/138#issuecomment-1918417382" expanded>

`nextBoolean()` scans only the next token which is `false`. It does not scan the `'\n'` after false. Hence the `nextLine()` will scan `'\n'` instead of the next line. You can use `s.skip("\n");` to fix this issue.
</panel>

<panel  header="**40 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/385#issuecomment-1962348425" expanded>

> It was discussed here: http://mail.openjdk.java.net/pipermail/openjfx-dev/2018-June/021977.html

Quote from the java.net link:

> This error comes from sun.launcher.LauncherHelper in the java.base module.
The reason for this is that the Main app extends Application and has a main
method. If that is the case, the LauncherHelper will check for the
javafx.graphics module to be present as a named module:

> Optional&lt;Module> om = ModuleLayer.boot().findModule(JAVAFX_GRAPHICS_MODULE_NAME);

> If that module is not present, the launch is aborted.
Hence, having the JavaFX libraries as jars on the classpath is not allowed
in this case.

In other words, it's the behaviour of sun.launcher.LauncherHelper itself. If you're interested you can read the source code here: https://github.com/AdoptOpenJDK/openjdk-jdk11/blob/master/src/java.base/share/classes/sun/launcher/LauncherHelper.java
</panel>

<panel  header="**43 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/559#issuecomment-2012777721" expanded>

There is an extensibility trade-off if you were to hardcode the strings directly in the tests.

For exmaple, if the `PREFIX` were to change in the future, the programmer would have to manually replace the strings in the test code, increasing the work required.

A similar issue occurs if you want to change the behaviour of a field in `Person`. With the original approach, as most of the strings are located in `CommandTestUtil.java`, it is relatively simple to update the tests. The other approach would require manually changing every hardcoded `name` string.

There are many questionable design choices in the AB3 code, and I believe that it's intended as part of the learning experience.
</panel>

It refers to the objects that are related to O by association. For example:

class A ``{``
    B b;
    void m() ``{`` ``}``
``}``

class B ``{``
    void otherMethod() ``{`` ``}``
``}``
```

In this case, `A::m` can call `b.otherMethod()` without violating the law of demeter.
</panel>

On the other hand, if creating many windows is not useful to users, and it is relatively "difficult" to create so many windows, then only a very small percentage of users would have this issue, so it can be considered Low.
If you can argue that the bug is due to a limitation of JavaFX or the operating system, making it impossible to fix from the developer's pov, then it's NotInScope.

> every time u would need to delete the class after finish using them no

Only if the object has no more references (i.e., ready for garbage collection). In this case, when `cook()` method returns, the `d` object is no longer referenced at that exact point in time, so the `X` is required (note that the return arrow coincides horizontally with the `X` to indicate that they occur at the same time).

In other cases, the object may continue being referenced and we may not know when it is ready for garbage collection.
</panel>

<panel  header="**7. :fas-info-circle: Clarification on duplicate issue.**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/883" expanded>


### Part 1
Say I'm a tester and I find some functionality bug through testing some command with the following integer inputs:

- `1` (works as intended)
- `0` (response not defined, command does not seem to work)
- `-1` (response not defined, command does not seem to work)

If the DG does not mention enough details about invalid inputs, I might assume that `0` and `-1` should fall into different equivalence partitions. Would it be reasonable to report them as 2 different issues during the PE? (since there's no penalty for reporting self-duplicates does it even matter?)

### Part 2
On the other hand, if I'm a dev and I receive these two as separate bugs, while it is possible to write two cases that handle `0` input and `-1` input independently, it feels like in real life, if I can show `0` and `-1` should reasonably fall under the same equivalence partition, then I would want to make one change that solves both cases. Would it make sense to mark the issue as a duplicate?
</panel>

<panel  header="**11. :fas-info-circle: 💎Automating Releases**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/697" expanded>

I was interested in finding a way to automate some parts of the release process. I ended up find this github action that helps (https://github.com/softprops/action-gh-release). This actions gets triggered every time an appropriate tag is pushed to the main team's repository, and helps create a draft release with the necessary `.jar` file uploaded. The relevant part of the workflow is here:

```
on:
  push:
    tags:
      - 'v1.*'

jobs:
  ...
      - name: Build Jar
        run: ./gradlew clean shadowJar

      - name: Create Release
        id: create_release
        uses: softprops/action-gh-release@v1
        with:
          draft: true
          prerelease: false
          files: build/libs/clinicmate.jar
          name: Release $``{`` github.ref_name ``}``
          tag_name: $``{`` github.ref ``}``
          fail_on_unmatched_files: true
          token: $``{`` secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN ``}``
```

We also created a modified version of this that generates a release every night using a cron job.

I think it would be cool if it were possible to generate and attach the user guide as well. If anyone has tried doing that do share below!
</panel>

<panel  header="**15. :fas-info-circle: Minor typo in w2.3c**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/30" expanded>

At the bottom of [W2.3c](https://nus-cs2103-ay2324s2.github.io/website/schedule/week2/topics.html#w2-3-rcs-revision-history) the course website currently states:

@RingoftheKing I feel it could be argued that this is just a naming difference, and that every adjective-like interface could be rephrased into a noun-like interface. For example, you could rename the interface into `IAbilityable` (representing something that is able to use an ability) and then you could say a Healer **IS-A** IAbilityable. The example of a `GetAreable` interface from [cs2030s](https://nus-cs2030s.github.io/2223-s2/18-interface.html#Interface) comes to mind.

More generally, I feel like in the OOP paradigm, Classes are always essentially just a promise of features (or perhaps a promise of specific methods being available). So maybe the distinction between the idea of a "promise of features" and the "IS-A relationship" is not so important?
</panel>

<panel  header="**24 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/263#issuecomment-1938820163" expanded>

@DominicFuMJ imports that start with `java.*` should usually appear before imports from other packages.

For example this would violate the checkstyle:

```
import duke.DukeException;
import java.time.LocalDate;
import duke.command.ByeCommand;
import duke.command.Command;
```

While this should not:

```
import java.time.LocalDate; # Notice that there is also a space after this import.

import duke.DukeException;
import duke.command.ByeCommand;
import duke.command.Command;
```
</panel>

@cheahTJ I believe it can be a useful way to start architecting a solution to a real world problem.

Like in the example given:
![image](https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/assets/110999129/d28cef5c-419e-458d-8224-3f462243a332)

If you start out by directly trying to create a Class Diagram (more methods, navigability, maybe even programming language specific features?) you might have to make a lot of edits every time you realise there's a problem, because there's more information to maintain. Since the OODM has less information, it means it's easier to change and maintain when you're still in some initial planning phase.

My guess would be that in a SWE team, if you're given a new project to solve some problem, you might try to see how different parts of the problem are linked conceptually, and so start out with a OODM/CCD. Once you're fairly certain that you've got a good idea of the problem, you could easily adapt your CCD into a Class Diagram (if appropriate/necessary) with a bit more detail. Or maybe you're not even using an OOP language, so you'll need to adapt your CCD into something appropriate for your team's tech stack.

<panel  header="**12 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/213#issuecomment-1927374015" expanded>

Without the `static` keyword, you can have multiple instances of the class, each having their own `STORAGE`. This could result in there being multiple different `STORAGE`s.

When you tag it as `final`, that means the `STORAGE` is a constant only within an instance of a class. So you can't change it throughout the lifetime of that object.

However when you declare something with the `static final` keywords, that means it is a constant that exists even without an instance of the class being created.

e.g.
If you have a `Math.PI` that has only been declared as `final` (no `static`), you could potentially have the following scenario

```java
Math Math1 = new Math(3.14);
Math Math2 = new Math(3.15);
Math Math3 = new Math(3);

Math1.PI = 3.14
Math2.PI = 3.15
Math3.PI = 3
```

But if you declare it with `static final`, you will be able to ensure that `Math.PI` always refers to the same value. You also would not need to instantiate the class to refer to that value.
</panel>

<panel  header="**1. :fas-info-circle: Clarification regarding Q3 and Q5 of the FAQ**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/680" expanded>

Q3 of the FAQ states that:
> A: In that case, we go by the reasonable 'correct' behavior that one expects. For example, the UG might not specify what happens if a user typed an extra space after the first keyword of the command (e.g., mark[SPACE]1 vs mark[SPACE][SPACE]1) in which case the reasonable correct behavior is to ignore the extra space.

and Q5 of the FAQ states that:
> A: Can be allowed only if the current behavior causes the software to misbehave (i.e., crash, give incorrect results, store inconsistent data, or make it unusable for typical users).
Accepting seemingly 'unsuitable' values for an input (e.g., accepting numbers for a person name, empty value as a parameter):
This is not considered 'incorrect' (giving more freedom to the user is not necessarily incorrect) unless those unsuitable values causes the application to misbehave.
Validity checks on edits to the data file:
As per AB3 UG (which states the current level of support for editing the data file manually), only valid edits will be supported. If the file is invalid, the app will start with an empty file (not crash). You may rectify only if the current level of support doesn't meet that bar. Furthermore, you may state in the UG that certain incorrect edits to the datafile can result in unexpected behaviors, and caution users to edit the file only if they know what they are doing.
Handling extraneous inputs (e.g., extra parameters, repeated parameters etc.) in commands:
The command 'forgiving' these extraneous inputs (i.e., giving an output same as or similar to if those inputs are not present) is not incorrect. You can mention in the UG that such inputs will be ignored. AB3 already does a similar thing for some commands. Any special handling of such inputs can be left as a future enhancement.

Our team's product has a bug whereby starting datetimes for an event can be after the ending datetime. This means that it does qualify as "incorrect behaviour" based on Q3. However, in Q5, we can tweak validity checks "only if the current behaviour causes the software to misbehave". Are we allowed to fix this bug?
</panel>

<panel  header="**7. :fas-info-circle: Help regarding OO design**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/247" expanded>

## The Aim
I'm aiming for code that is easily extensible in the sense that I can add new types of `Task` and `Handler`(a class encapsulating a the response to a command) easily. Therefore I want utility classes like `Storage` and `Parser` to only see `Task` and `Handler` instead of the specific subtypes like `TodoTask`. 

### What I Did
So far, I elected to use the Factory design pattern where there is a `TaskFactory` class that is responsible for creating a `Task` of the correct concrete subclass through a factory method, and similarly for `Handler`. This is an improvement over a previous design where `Task` itself handled the creation of subclasses, but this meant it "knew" its own subclasses, breaking abstraction. The intention is that adding a new type of task or command amounts to simply defining a new subclass of `Task` and/or new subclasses of `Handler` (for the associated commands), and modifying the factory methods' switch cases.

### The Problem
However, suppose the `Parser` has the following static methods:
```java
public static LocalDateTime parseDateTime(String dateTime) ``{``
    return LocalDateTime.parse(dateTime, DATETIME_FORMAT);
``}``

public static Task parseStorageEntry(String entry) ``{``
    String[] data = entry.split(",");
    return TaskFactory.of(data);
``}``
```
Somewhere down the line, `TaskFactory` will require `parseDateTime` to function, so I understand it as circularly dependent (Parser -&gt; TaskFactory -&gt; *Task -&gt; Parser). So to prevent this I think I can either
1. Separate `Parser` more finely into `StorageParser`, `InputParser`, `DateTimeParser`, `AuxiliaryParser`, etc. This means `StorageParser` and `InputParser` are dependent on `Task` and `Handler` which are dependent on sibling classes `DataTimeParser` and `AuxiliaryParser`. But the main thing that doesn't feel right to me here is that none of these parser classes share fields or methods so do I just leave them as separate unrelated classes? I read of something called [marker interfaces](https://www.baeldung.com/java-marker-interfaces), - should I make them all implement an empty `Parser` interface to symbolize that they have a static `parse` method? (The methods are static thus the subclasses can't override some generic `parse`).
2. Again separate `Parser` into more specific subclasses, but make the `parse` methods generic and not static, meaning it can be overridden. So instead of the current approach where `Parser.parse*` can be invoked without instantiating a class, specific parsers need to be instantiated. Is this a better design over the previous?
3. Not have a `Parser`. Is this allowed?

I could also be going down the wrong direction entirely, if that is so do advise. Thanks in advance for any help.

Small edit: on the topic of enums I found [enum factory pattern](https://jvmaware.com/enum-as-factory/). On top of the options listed above there is another option of making the subclasses of `Task` handle date time by themselves, but this means that each subclass potentially has a different format.
</panel>

A possible program flow is thus
```java

boolean isFileMade = file.createNewFile();
if (isFolderMade || isFileMade) ``{``

``}``
```

<panel  header="**9 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/110#issuecomment-1919582563" expanded>

Hi @tankh99, I too am inclined towards keeping them in the same file for consideration of code complexity and potential points of failure. Since we will have to perform more file IO operations, I thought that multiple files may give rise to a situation whereby data is desynchronized if say one of three write operations fail. Suppose it is the last write operation that failed, I'd then have decide if I should undo the previous two writes. Also if new types of tasks were required in future it might be harder to refactor.

Using the `split` method of strings to read from files like `String[] taskInfo = line.split(",")` has worked well for me as regular expressions are quite robust, but a conditional switch is still necessary to choose the type of task to instantiate. I'm also thinking it can be used in some cases to handle cases where the user enters extraneous whitespaces also to guard against weird formatting when saving it to the disk. In example, for taking input from the user,
```java
String[] command = sc.nextLine().split("\\s+(/(from|to|by)\\s+)?");
```
and something similar may be able to recover from extraneous characters when reading from the file.

That said, I do see advantages for keeping the files separate in that it's easier to recover from a corrupted task type, and storage could be optimized for each type of task or have specialized handling of each type, and error handling is more readable for more specialized code. 

Maybe there could be some middle ground like storing the different types together in a file but creating handlers for each new type as separate classes or files. It does seem overly ambitious though as it's mostly to accommodate adding of new types without guarantee that it will be a requirement. If anyone has any thoughts on this, do advise.
</panel>

<panel  header="**10 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/199#issuecomment-1926143062" expanded>

I think the key here is to recognize that we are familiar with our editors expanding our tab input as some number of spaces, but tabs as actual tab characters is different from whitespaces. 

The arguments for using spaces instead of tabs would be suppose you had to wrap a line but line up function parameters, it is likely tabs and spaces need to be mixed to align it exactly. Yet tab widths could differ from device to device, so it may look different when transferred to another device. For languages like python where indentation matters, mixing of tabs and spaces could lead to errors, and may not be easy to visually catch. Spaces are also more consistent when copied over to e.g. forums, the web. So overall, tabs tend to require spaces on top of tabs anyways, and spaces are more robust.
</panel>

<panel  header="**14 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/243#issuecomment-1936353041" expanded>

Hi @ejnan, you didn't specify what does not work so I'm assuming your question is why your code does not parse times involving AM and PM. If so, the issue originates in line 32 of your `DateTimeUtils`
```java
.parseDefaulting(ChronoField.HOUR_OF_DAY, 23) // Default to end of day (23:59)
```
`ChronoField.HOUR_OF_DAY` is for 24 hour time, so it conflicts with AM and PM. You can try the following to see that it's what's causing it to throw an error.
```java
import java.time.LocalDate;
import java.time.LocalDateTime;
import java.time.format.DateTimeFormatter;
import java.time.format.DateTimeFormatterBuilder;
import java.time.temporal.ChronoField;
import java.util.Locale;

public class Test ``{``
    public static void main(String[] args) ``{``
        DateTimeFormatter formatter = new DateTimeFormatterBuilder()
                .appendPattern("d/M/yyyy h:mm a")
                .parseDefaulting(ChronoField.YEAR_OF_ERA, LocalDate.now().getYear())
                // .parseDefaulting(ChronoField.HOUR_OF_DAY, 23) // Default to end of day (23:59)
                // .parseDefaulting(ChronoField.MINUTE_OF_HOUR, 59)
                .parseDefaulting(ChronoField.CLOCK_HOUR_OF_AMPM, 11)
                .parseDefaulting(ChronoField.AMPM_OF_DAY, 1)
                .parseCaseInsensitive()
                .toFormatter(Locale.ENGLISH);
        String input = "2/12/2022 6:30 PM";
        LocalDateTime dateTime = LocalDateTime.parse(input, formatter);
        System.out.println(dateTime);
    ``}``
``}``
```
That said I agree with @kokerinks that it's worth considering restructuring the code for handling date time (as the next increment after Level-8 involves major refactoring, so you can spare yourself some pain here).
</panel>

>Why doesn't an AssertionError allow access to the object that generated it? Similarly, why not pass an arbitrary object from the assertion to the AssertionError constructor in place of a detail message? Access to these objects would encourage programmers to attempt to recover from assertion failures, which defeats the purpose of the facility.

>Why is AssertionError a subclass of Error rather than RuntimeException? This issue was controversial. The expert group discussed it at length, and came to the conclusion that Error was more appropriate to discourage programmers from attempting to recover from assertion failures.

I feel the resource is trying to convey that unlike error handling, which allows your program to gracefully recover from any error, asserts are not meant to be "recovered" from. They are more of a tool to help the programmer detect and correct bugs during testing and also tell readers information (like that of control flow invariants, assert false is a nice way to indicate default is never executed).

Using assertions to do input validation is also dangerous since it can be turned off, so if it is in any way important to the logic of the program it is fatal.
</panel>

<panel  header="**43 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/1007#issuecomment-2077143692" expanded>

Concur that \*..5 is probably wrong?

Bit of trivia the [Kleene star](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kleene_star) ($\&hat;\*$) applied to a set of strings means "any number of repetitions of strings from the set". e.g. $\\``{``a,b\\``}``\&hat;\*=\\``{``\epsilon, a, b, aa, bb, ab, ba, aaa, bbb, \dots \\``}``$. This is where the use of \* in regex comes from. I see it as $a\&hat;1=a$, $a\&hat;2=aa$, $a\&hat;3=aaa$ so $a\&hat;\*$ is like a wildcard exponent. I guess \* tends to have the meaning of "any number of".
</panel>

<panel  header="**23 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/583#issuecomment-2017114877" expanded>

It seems like `Objects.requireNonNull(x)` is better since it is explicitly designed for parameter validation in methods and constructors. Additionally, assert statements seem to be better left out of production code since we can still recover from exceptions thrown by `Objects.requireNonNull(x)` whereas we're meant to use assertions in testing and bug-fixing and allow exceptions from assertions to happen

Moreover `Objects.requireNonNull(x)` being a method instead of a keyword like `assert` allows us to pass in the results of another methods directly into the null-check instead of create a variable first and then compare that variable using `assert`

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/60712593/should-you-assert-not-null-with-the-assert-statement-in-production-code
</panel>

<panel  header="**24 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/584#issuecomment-2017118093" expanded>

While its true that at the scale of AB3 its meaningless to talk about asymptotic performance, I feel like if O(n) was possible we should go for it? **As long as its readable** then writing more efficient methods now just saves future work when the product does need to be much more scalable.

Even for readability, we can use abstraction to hide the confusing details that tend to crop up with cleverer methods. The user of a search method for example does not need to see that a binary-search is implemented as opposed to be a simple for-loop
</panel>

<panel  header="**20 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/294#issuecomment-1948716455" expanded>

`\/\*\*\s+?\* \w+?(?&lt;!s)\b` has a negative lookbehind to not capture anything inside the (?&lt;!)

`\/\*\*\s+?\* (?!.+?s\b).` (I realised the one above had a few errors) is a negative lookahead to not capture anything inside the (?!) and only match after.

I suspect it's a error on my part, can't say I'm the best at lookarounds

TIL there's regex quantifiers too, regex is way too complicated haha

But thanks!

Edit: I just tried `\/\*\*\s+?\* (?!.+?s\b).` and it doesn't work in `checkstyle`, but seems to work on https://regex101.com/
</panel>

<panel  header="**21 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/294#issuecomment-1948974964" expanded>

Yep have checked the flavour. 
Also you can't greedily (or even lazily) match `.` before the negative lookahead because you don't know how much to match `.` before checking for the lookahead. 
Thanks though.
</panel>

I think the question here is to achieve `100% path overage`. The number of paths through the loop is very large, as each possible length of `s` produces a unique path. 

So in your example `s = null` and `s.length() = 1` will not cover 100% path coverage as the path of iterating two times is not covererd.
</panel>

<panel  header="**29 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/989#issuecomment-2079217345" expanded>

If I'm understanding correctly, the difference is that
- `padding` is when you are confident that you need 3 days, but you still add 2 extra days to the deliverable deadline. (You do not need these 2 days)
- `buffer` is when you estimate that you need 3 days based on current information, but you add 2 extra days to absorb any unforeseen delays. (You do need these 2 days as effort/time estimations are hard in this case)
</panel>

<panel  header="**9 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/120#issuecomment-1914179590" expanded>

Hi, 
Judging from your code, you seem to be iterating through your list and rewriting to FILE, which would lead to multiple overwriting of a single task. 
If that is the case, you can create a FileWriter object that appends to the file (instead of overwriting the current content) by specifying an additional boolean parameter to the constructor.
For Example: `FileWriter fw = new FileWriter(FILE, true); ` 

I would also suggest wrapping your code in a code block and also providing other useful information to help with debugging this issue such as `FILE`, `createFile()` etc.

</panel>

<panel  header="**5. :fas-info-circle: Legality of Changes in 1.4**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/758" expanded>

A tester raised an [issue](https://github.com/AY2324S2-CS2103T-F12-2/tp/issues/179) regarding the program doing nothing when it takes in garbage values, which in this case is a start date being later than an end date.
I had written an unique class exception 'InvalidDatesException' for this and thrown this exception. However, it turns out that the code will only display error messages related to parse exceptions, so the command with garbage values will be rejected, but the error message will not be shown.

To fix this, I added this chunk of code 
' catch (InvalidDatesException x) ``{``
            throw new ParseException(x.getMessage());``}``'
But my team worries that this may count as enhancement, and therefore violate the feature freeze. To add on, the user can currently tell that the command does not work as nothing happens when they enter the garbage command.

<panel  header="**5. :fas-info-circle: 💡Accessing PR using Github CLI without pulling from PR branch**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/530" expanded>

if you download GitHub CLI, you can view PRs and run them locally without having to pull from a peer's PR branch.
After you download the CLI

```
gh auth login
gh repo set-default <team-repo-name>
gh pr checkout <PR-id>
```

Hope this helps!
Creds to @evedaktyl
</panel>

<panel  header="**20 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/176#issuecomment-2002932243" expanded>

From what I gathered online and from gpt, instance (non-static) implementation allows for polymorphism and dynamic binding, whereas a static implementaion does allow for that, you could implement child classes that has the same static method, but you cannot "override" the parent method, which is not as OO as an instance implementation.

For instance, if you have different types of parsers or user interfaces, using instance methods allows you to define a common interface or base class and then provide specific implementations for each variant. This way, you can easily switch between different parsers or UIs at runtime, depending on the context or configuration, without changing the underlying system architecture.

Hope this makes sense.
</panel>

I tried the given command, but it requires me to give a tagging message. After further research on https://git-scm.com/book/en/v2/Git-Basics-Tagging, looks like we can either make **lightweight** or **annotated** tags.

For **lightweight** tags:
git tag ``{``tagname``}``

For **annotated** tags:
git tag -a ``{``tagname``}`` -m ``{``tagging message``}``

I raise this issue to ask whether we need to specify tagging message when creating tag, and also highlight the attention of the teaching team if any rectification on the given material is required.

<panel  header="**18 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/593#issuecomment-2057364496" expanded>

Hi, in my opinion, if `doMoreStuff()` is meant to be a general function that can be used by a number of methods, it will indeed be good to let it be less restrictive. On the other hand, if `doMoreStuff()` is a private helper method only for `doSomething()`, then it make sense to let it be restrictive in order to maintain the single layer of abstraction in `doSomething()`.

As an alternative, perhaps you can use `class B`, but add another function called `doMoreStuffIfNotB()`. E.g.
```java
void doMoreStuffIfNotB(boolean b) ``{``
    if (!b) ``{``
       // ...
    ``}``
``}``
```

Then any method that needs them, e.g. `doSomething()` can do:
```java
void doSomething(boolean b) ``{``
   doStuff();
   doMoreStuffIfB(b);
   doMoreStuffIfNotB(b);
``}``
```


</panel>

<panel  header="**6. :fas-info-circle: Bidirectional vs 2 Unidirectional Associations**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/192" expanded>


Hello, in this weeks topic we learnt that two unidirectional associations in opposite directions do not add up to a single bidirectional association.
"In the code below, there is a bidirectional association between the Person class and the Cat class i.e., if Person p is the owner of the Cat c, p it will result in p and c having references to each other."

```
class Person ``{``
    Cat pet;
    //...
``}``

class Cat``{``
    Person owner;
    //...
``}``

```
"The code below has two unidirectional associations between the Person class and the Cat class (in opposite directions) because the breeder is not necessarily the same person keeping the cat as a pet i.e., there are two separate associations here, which rules out it being a bidirectional association."
```
class Person ``{``
    Cat pet;
    //...
``}``

class Cat``{``
    Person breeder;
    //...
``}``
```

Just to confirm/clarify a few things:
- In terms of the way our code is implemented, there is no difference between the 2, ie the code is essentially identical other than the variable names. The main point of this example is just to highlight there may be a difference in how our code is **intended** on being used. The semantics of these relationships would then influence the way we should model them in a class diagram.
- Building from this example, assume that we want Cats to have both breeder and owner attributes, and a Person may be a breeder (no Breeder class) and owner. Should we use 3 different association lines between Person and Cat class to represent a owner-pet association (1 bidirectional arrow) and a breeder-animal association (2 unidirectional arrows)? 

 Thank you!
</panel>

When refactoring our code to achieve A-MoreOOP, we had to create many new classes and integrate them into the main logic of our program. I realised that as I started refactoring it, creating new classes, it kind of depended on other new classes as well and my entire code broke until i successfully finished refactoring the code in all (old and new) classes. 

As a result, this was just one commit with many many changes. I feel like this is not the "correct" way to do it but i am not sure. Should we be instead creating classes one by one and integrating it into our main code? However, I think this would also have a lot of unnecessary refactoring as you go through each iteration.

**TLDR:**
1. What are the best practices for managing dependencies and smoothly integrating new classes with existing ones during a refactor, to keep the codebase functional throughout the process

2. In this (depth-first?) refactoring approach where new dependencies are introduced, is it advisable to commit changes even if the code is temporarily non-functional, or should commits only be made once the code is stable?

<panel  header="**9 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/126#issuecomment-1917478510" expanded>

Hi everyone, 

Thank you for all your valuable insights. 

I just did a quick summary of the key takeaways from this discussion:

**Modular Integration**: Adopt a module-by-module approach to integration, as recommended by @tankh99 and @wilsonwid. This helps to isolate and debug issues more efficiently.

**Granular Commits:** Make smaller, more frequent commits. This ensures the codebase remains functional and facilitates easier debugging, as mentioned by @itstrueitstrueitsrealitsreal and @ys112.

**Planning and Visualization**: Before coding, plan out functionalities and their relationships. This approach, highlighted by @NeoHW and @qinxutan, provides a clear roadmap for refactoring. We can also draw high level diagrams and map out the various has-a, is-a relationships between the classes as suggested by @appleraincoat and @UdhayaShan1 

Maintain Functional Code: Aim to keep the codebase functional at every step of the refactoring process, as emphasized by @sun-ruiheng and @hjungwoo01.


TLDR: Best practices seem to include modular integration, making step-by-step commits, strategic planning, while maintaining functional code. 

Thanks everyone for the collective wisdom! I'll be marking this issue as resolved.

</panel>

<panel  header="**9 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/219#issuecomment-1931369721" expanded>

I think the Prof. has answered your main question quite well, just some extra input from me as to custom exception handling since I also noticed this when I was doing the PR Review.

Personally, I prefer having multiple custom Exception classes (i.e., `InvalidCommandException`, `InvalidArgumentsException`) so that I can distinguish the different scenarios rather than having a simple catch-all `DukeException` class. This also allows you to define specific formats for the messages so that it is clearly standardised without having to copy paste the error message string multiple times.

Quick Example: 
```
public class InvalidCommandException extends Exception ``{``
        public InvalidCommandException(String invalidCommand) ``{``
            super("Invalid Command: " + invalidCommand + " received.\nOnly the following commands are accepted: list, add, bye";
        ``}``
    ``}``
```
</panel>

## Editing sample data to be more like real-use

## Fixing Integer overflow
Currently, if an entry in our address book has `2147483647 points`, trying to add 1 point to the member will result in no change to points, but also no error/success message. On the other hand, another field our app stores in the same situation results in the field changing from `2147483647` to `-2147483648`. Can we introduce a maximum points (i.e 2,000,000,000) to prevent these from happening? Or can we only list this behaviour in the UG and park this under planned enhancements?

## Side question
Extreme values unlikely to appear with normal use, such as a name that is 300 characters long, cannot be fully shown in the UI in any way. Would this be considered a feature flaw in the PE?

<panel  header="**9 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/61#issuecomment-1906779090" expanded>

@bgopi23 I encountered a similar issue hence ended up in this post, these are my personal findings

1) For Level-0, upon completing my requirements and staging my changes, I did the following:
`git push`
`git push --tags`
This resulted in normal behaviour without the error message.

2) For Level-1,  upon completing my requirements and staging my changes, I did the following:
`git push --tags`
This resulted me in getting the same error as you did (Sorry forgot to screenshot)
Then, as suggested by prof @damithc, I did
`git push`
Which fixed the problem upon refreshing my github page

I suspect that you, like me, are doing `git push --tags`, thinking that this pushes both commits and tags but in reality it only pushes tags. Even though you can see the changes in the code from the tag, I think (correct me if I'm wrong) that its not how version control is meant to be done. From what you have described, it sounds like you have already done multiple "Levels" this way and I'm not sure how you can resolve it from there.

Maybe you can do the following (Someone else please advise if this is okay):
1. Delete all your tags on github and local repo
2. Do `git push` to push all your commits for the levels you have done
3. Tag all the levels you have done (on local repo)
4. Do `git push --tags` to push all the tags

I came up with this suggestion based on this FAQ on the website
![image](https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/assets/84035425/359d4965-00ed-4f52-a121-b8cdbbcc2c2b)

Hope I helped, thanks!
</panel>

> `nextBoolean()` scans only the next token which is `false`. It does not scan the `'\n'` after false. Hence the `nextLine()` will scan `'\n'` instead of the next line. You can use `s.skip("\n");` to fix this issue.

<panel  header="**4. :fas-info-circle: Incorrect value displayed - should the success message or the logic of the code be changed?**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/818" expanded>

Hi Prof @damithc, we are considering two approaches to modifying a problematic behaviour in our app and would like to see whether either/both of them are allowed.

- Currently, two of our commands (`linkloan` and `editloan`) allow passing in of a monetary value (the loan value) as a parameter.
- In our v1.3 UG, it was stated for `linkloan` that the loan value must be (up) to 2d.p., following the general consensus that money should be to at most 2 decimal places. However, we missed out including this for `editloan` (bug in the UG). It must be noted that it does not make much sense for `linkloan` to disallow > 2d.p. but `editloan` to allow it.
- Right now our `linkloan` command is erroneously able to accept > 2d.p. values. The > 2d.p. values are accepted by the app and stored correctly, and displayed correctly when a user accesses the loan. This bug was reported by testers in v1.3 due to its difference from the UG.
- However, the success message displays the loan to only 2d.p. (i.e rounds it off) as we implemented the success message to show 2d.p. values, since it was intended for only 2d.p. values to be accepted. For instance, a loan of `0.0001` would be displayed as `0.00` in the success message. Therefore, this might fall under _incorrect results_ in Q5 of the FAQs for the feature freeze, since the value displayed in the success message is not the value the user entered.

Which of these two lines of thinking would be allowed to approach the issue while maintaining adherence to the feature freeze?

1.  The issue is in the `linkloan` command being to accept 2d.p. values, since our v1.3 user guide says it doesn't. We should modify our `linkloan` (and possibly by extension, `editloan`?) command(s) to reject values that are more than 2d.p., upon which the success message will always be correct.
2. The issue is in the success message rounding the loan to 2d.p. We should modify the success message to allow it to show more than 2d.p. in the loan value, and edit the UG to remove the part saying the loan value must be (up) to 2d.p.

Here are some screenshots for reference:
![image](https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/assets/122250318/acf4705c-793c-4834-861b-bc6ddccf9a98)
Adding a > 2d.p. loan to the user (not supposed to be allowed...) which succeeds

Success message does not show the loan value correctly
![image](https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/assets/122250318/6b267aa3-f2e6-455d-98af-2b5399170e4a)
But when viewing the user's loans, the loan value is shown correctly (and it is also stored correctly)

<panel  header="**14 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/998#issuecomment-2076531066" expanded>

> If history is deleted, wont all repeatable objects be deleted too since its stored as a list inside history?

From my understanding, the repeatable objects will still exist.
For example, a repeatable object may be stored in multiple histories. It does not make sense that deleting a history will delete repeatable objects stored in other histories.

Another analogy would be Person objects stored inside a Queue object. The people would not be deleted if the Queue object is deleted.
</panel>

`error: The following untracked working tree files would be overwritten by merge:`

means that there is some file in your directory that is not committed. In this case, your current branch data/logfile.txt has been edited, while the branch you are trying to merge from has another data/logfile.txt. Since this is not an important file, you can add it to .gitignore, or simply delete this file and merge.

I have found out a way to ensure the availability of emotes. 

I have also encountered similar issues on emojis too (emojis not showing, just like above). I copied the emojis online and pasted it into the README.md, but it is not shown at all in the website!

The way I resolve this is by typing `:` into the markdown, and the list of available emojis will appear. As far as I concern, I still have not encountered any single case where the emojis disappear when using the method above.

Another thing worth noting is, even when the emoji is available on github, for example: 🖼️ (\:framed_picture), it might not appear on your website if you copied and pasted from online.
You can try this on your markdown
Using the `:` method: 🖼️

```java
private int compareTaskByDate(Object o1, Object o2) ``{``
        if (o1 instanceof Todo) ``{``
            return 1;
        ``}``
        if (o2 instanceof Todo) ``{``
            return -1;

        if (o1 instanceof Deadline) ``{``
            if (o2 instanceof Deadline) ``{``
                return ((Deadline) o1).getBy().compareTo(((Deadline) o2).getBy());
            ``}``
            if (o2 instanceof Event) ``{``
                return ((Deadline) o1).getBy().compareTo(((Event) o2).getBy());
            ``}``
        ``}``
        if (o1 instanceof Event) ``{``
            if (o2 instanceof Deadline) ``{``
                return ((Event) o1).getBy().compareTo(((Deadline) o2).getBy());
            ``}``
            if (o2 instanceof Event) ``{``
                return ((Event) o1).getBy().compareTo(((Event) o2).getBy());
            ``}``
        ``}``
        return 0;
    ``}``
```

<panel  header="**11 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/1018#issuecomment-2077047916" expanded>

For the 2nd CCD, I think you are misunderstanding the diagram, as it is not necessary to have 2 instances of the instructor. The `InstructorRole` and `CoordinatorRole` are classes, and new objects of these roles are created whenever there is a new instructor/coordinator added to a course. The person object is simply associated with these role objects, and the same person object is used if the person has multiple roles. An example of this can be seen on the bottom right (the one with no black background).

I believe this provides more flexibility as it allows for specific fields added to each role. An example is the `isPastCoord` in the 2nd diagram, and more can be added to either role classes if required.

I don't think one is "better" than the other, and either one can be used depending on whether you would like to model it focusing more on simplicity or flexibility.
</panel>

</panel>

<panel  header="**5 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/126#issuecomment-1916341014" expanded>

That's exactly an issue I grappled with, because the way I prefer to refactor is not very easy to track, as you mentioned.

When coding them out, I actually prefer to write code for the "highest level" classes first (e.g. Duke, TaskList), sort of defining the API, before getting the detailed smaller classes (like Storage, Task) to fulfil the API. This ensures you have full control over the structure of your program from the start. However, this runs into the exact problem you are describing.

The safer approach might be to work ground-up by creating the smaller classes first. You would need to have a clear plan of which methods / functionalities go into which classes, very clearly defining the I/O offered by each class. Then, begin with the smaller classes that don't depend on others, so you're adding new classes such as Storage while keeping your main long Duke file the same as before — throughout the process, your newly created classes are used minimally, if at all. Then once the smaller classes are done, you can refactor your main Duke class to incorporate their use. This way, there exists working code every step.
</panel>

For this bug, in order to fix this bug, is it okay if I can parse the search query (e.g. `/search ; salary : $50/hr`) without making any changes to the validation of the search input. Because the feature flaw was that I did not use validation for `search` command, so would fixing this search functionality bug in order to search by integer without making any changes to the validation, be okay?

<panel  header="**4 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/759#issuecomment-2047484831" expanded>

From the user point of view, the current behaviour allows users to key in any String input without any validation to search for salary, and the search command works by matching the String query with existing String input. In this case, we identified this lack of input validation as our feature flaw. By right, our Salary field follows this format `$X/hr`, but the search command does not perform this validation, so users can key in anything from `$`, `$5`, `50` etc.

But the current functionality bug is that if the user searches for example, `$5`, the search command returns all contacts with salary field containing this string, which unfortunately includes `$50/hr`. This is clearly a bug as I used String search to perform the search.

The proposed new bahaviour to fix the bug would be to parse salary through a parser to trim the extra terms and search by matching the integer, but the main issue is that would it be alright if I use the parser without making any changes to validation (i.e. still allow invalid inputs), in order not to violate the feature freeze? Or would it be okay to add validation to reject invalid parsed inputs in this case?
</panel>

1. git merge --no-ff add-gradle-support (merge the gradle branch to your main)
2. run ./gradlew build (if you see build successful you have implemented gradle)
3. run ./gradlew run

Including a **tag message** with an annotated tag can provide additional context about the tag.
This message can describe the reason for the tag, such as a release version, a significant change, or a milestone in the project.

```
git tag -a <tagname> -m "Tag message"
```
For example,
```
git tag -a v1.0 -m "Release version 1.0
```

<panel  header="**1. :fas-info-circle: A Tricky Tester Response Scenario (context added)**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/955" expanded>

I'm reposting this since additional context was requested.

I tested the commands `sort price` and `sort salary` during the PE (both are "numerical" fields). I notice that `sort price` sorts the prices using string comparison while `sort salary` sorts the salaries in increasing numerical order. I proceeded to report `sort price` as a `type.FunctionalityBug` (without mentioning sorting by salary).

Now, the team rejected the bug and claimed that string comparison is intended, quoting the UG that sorting is done in lexicographical order (they mentioned this in the UG). However, this behaviour contradicts with a user story in the DG.

Now I'm in a disadvantaged position since I did not mention the inconsistency between sorting by price and salary during the PE.

My options right now:
Option A: Argue the bug as a `type.FeatureFlaw` (since it contradicts with the DG). (I did not mention the DG in the original bug report. Am I allowed to add this information in?)
Option B: Proceed to argue the inconsistent behaviour of sorting by salary and report that as a `type.FunctionalityBug`. (I did not mention the sorting by price in the original bug report. Am I allowed to add this information in?)
Option C: Continue arguing that sorting by price should be done in increasing numerical order and thus it should be a `type.FunctionalityBug`. (Is this reasonable?)

In particular, may I check what is the allowable extent of quoting additional information during the tester response phase?  

If all of my options do not work, I feel that there is a loophole in this PE so that teams can write ambiguous documentation and reject bugs testers have reported by suddenly claiming that the behaviour is intended.

Will appreicate any advice on this. Thanks!

Link to the issue (for reference): https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/pe-dev-response/issues/4739.
</panel>

<panel  header="**2. :fas-info-circle: A Tricky Tester Response Scenario**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/938" expanded>

I will be using variables below for simplicity.

I tested commands `A` and `B` during the PE and they have inconsistent behaviours with each other. According to my judgement, command `A` has the correct behavior while command `B` doesn't. I proceeded to report the incorrect output of command `B` under `type.FunctionalityBug` (without mentioning command `A` at all).

However, now that the dev team argued that command `B` has the correct behaviour (which implies command `A` doesn't). It is possible to argue that the behaviour is consistent with the user guide (with ambiguity), while it clearly contradicts with the user stories in the DG.

What should I do in the tester response phase?

Action 1: Forgo the bug since I did not mention command `A` in the bug report.
Action 2: Continue arguing that command `B` has an incorrect behaviour. (i.e. disagree with the rejection)
Action 3: Adopt the team's logic but state that command `B` has a severe feature flaw.
Action 4: Report an issue with documentation.

All of Actions 2, 3 and 4 seem weird to me (and I'm not sure whether they are allowed), but choosing Action 1 means that there is a loophole in the PE which allows teams to get away with serious bugs (rather easily).

May someone advise for this? Thanks!
</panel>

<panel  header="**4 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/90#issuecomment-1913016533" expanded>

Yes, Java packages must correspond to the directory structure. `package src.main.java.utilities;` must be placed under the directory `src/main/java/utilities`.

In your case, it's better to create a common folder (say, duke) and place all your subfolders inside that common folder. Then, you can declare packagaes like duke.tasks, duke.utilities, etc.
</panel>

<panel  header="**1 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/65#issuecomment-1911608159" expanded>

> I found that cd-ing into the test folder each time to run it is a pain, so I used a SCRIPT_DIR so that you can run it outside of the folder. Feel free to copy and use.

Instead of using `$SCRIPT_DIR` to store the script's directory and `cd` to it, you can just wrap the script with `pushd` and `popd`.

```bash
#!/usr/bin/env bash
# Change the current directory to the directory of this script
pushd "$(dirname "$0")" >/dev/null

# create bin directory if it doesn't exist
# ... the rest of your script

# Change back to the original directory
popd > /dev/null
```

You don't have to add `$SCRIPT_DIR` to every path anymore. 2 additional lines are not excessively long 😛
</panel>
