<panel  header="**7 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/545#issuecomment-2013242555" expanded>

Hi, I am tagged so I figured that I might as well pitch in, despite the fact that this seems to have been resolved. It might be helpful to contribute my process of figuring out the cause of the error. I came to the same conclusion as @seanfirefox did.

I cloned the fork, pulled the problematic branch and `checkout`ed the problematic commit `1a033d06` (according to the PR timeline, this is the commit right before the PR is mentioned in this issue). I tried to run all tests and indeed 99 out of 310 tests have failed.

In particular, the `execute_storageThrowsAdException_throwsCommandException` test failed. The IDE shows that an `ExceptionInInitializerError` has been thrown. I searched online for information relevant to this error and found this [resource](https://www.baeldung.com/java-exceptionininitializererror) helpful. It turns out that the `Caused by: ...` section of the error message shows exactly which line of the static initializer is causing the error.

```
Caused by: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Date must be in dd-MM-yyyy HH:mm format.
Date & time must be after the current time.
Time of appointment must be on the hour.
	at seedu.address.commons.util.AppUtil.checkArgument(AppUtil.java:39)
	at seedu.address.model.meeting.Meeting.<init>(Meeting.java:48)
	at seedu.address.testutil.MeetingBuilder.build(MeetingBuilder.java:72)
	at seedu.address.testutil.PersonBuilder.withDefaultMeetingA(PersonBuilder.java:107)
	at seedu.address.testutil.TypicalPersons.<clinit>(TypicalPersons.java:60)
```

As per the resource given, `<clinit>` is the class initializer method. Line 60 in `TypicalPersons.java` seems to be part of a statement that is causing the issue.

```java
public static final Person JAMAL = new PersonBuilder().withName("Jamal").withPhone("88888888")
            .withEmail("jamal@example.com").withAddress("little india").withDefaultMeetingA().build();
```

Following the stack trace, `withDefaultMeetingA` calls `MeetingBuilder#build`, which calls the `Meeting` constructor, which calls `checkArgument`, which throws an `IllegalArgumentException`. Here is the `checkArgument` method:

```java
public static void checkArgument(Boolean condition, String errorMessage) ``{``
    if (!condition) ``{``
        throw new IllegalArgumentException(errorMessage);
    ``}``
``}``
```

Looking into the `Meeting` constructor, we know that `isValidDateTime(dateTime.format(formatter))` evaluated to false, where `dateTime` has the value of `LocalDateTime.parse("05-02-2024 13:00", formatter)` and `formatter` has the value of `DateTimeFormatter.ofPattern("dd-MM-yyyy HH:mm")`.

The `isValidDateTime(dateTime.format(formatter))` method essentially checks whether `"05-02-2024 13:00"` is before `LocalDateTime.now()`, and returns false if so. Now we see why `checkArgument` throws an `IllegalArgumentException`, ultimately causing the `ExceptionInInitializerError` and the test cases to fail.

> I am not even calling withDefaultMeetingA though, I am quite confused as i only added two small methods to Person.java and it is breaking everywhere.

We can figure this out by looking at where exactly did `ExceptionInInitializerError` occurs. The IDE shows that it occurred in the `assertCommandFailureForExceptionFromStorage` method, on line 170. This method is being called by`execute_storageThrowsAdException_throwsCommandException`, which is one of the tests that will be run when we run all tests. On line 170, the test makes use of `AMY` from the `TypicalPersons` class, so the class initializer method (the so-called `<clinit>`) of `TypicalPersons` is being executed, which will initialise all the static variables in the class, among which is the problematic `JAMAL`, which calls `withDefaultMeetingA`.
</panel>

</panel>

I understood 'components' as parts of the code that focuses on various responsibilities, and 'cohesion' as the degree to which the components belong together, directed towards performing a single task. If theres one task (in this case, to interact with user), as part of SoC principle, we would be letting one component (GUI class) handle it to prevent functional overlap rather than combining with another class (with an unrelated responsibility). 
<img width="544" alt="image" src="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/assets/103313573/dda26ef5-c19c-46ce-9220-8ce816f6b587">
From the explanation &hat;, we can see that by isolating the GUI class, we know the GUI class' sole responsibility IS in user interaction, thus all the code in GUI class are highly related to perform this same task, achieving high cohesion. 
</panel>

<panel  header="**4 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/104#issuecomment-1913465681" expanded>

My decision was to just allow one date and time format. Advantages are that it's unambiguous and easy to implement. My code throws an error if it's not in that one format.

There is also the alternative design idea of having a custom flexible time system similar to how [taskwarrior](https://taskwarrior.org/docs/dates/#synonyms-hahahugoshortcode-s0-hbhb) does it. It's less cumbersome and faster from a UX standpoint, but it's scope is probably way too big for a project like this.

Keeping backwards compatibility as a string won't really make sense if any filtering based on date is implemented later, but maybe they can be kept around for output purposes.
</panel>

<panel  header="**2. :fas-info-circle: Using checkstyle.jar with google_checks.xml**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/88" expanded>


Hello, I tried to use [Checkstyle](https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/tree/master) to check the coding standard of my iP.

The xml file that it is checking against is [google_checks.xml](https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/blob/master/src/main/resources/google_checks.xml).

I used this config file as the [Java coding standard](https://se-education.org/guides/conventions/java/intermediate.html) stated the following:

<panel type="info" header="### 101. YEO ..HENG `@yeoshuheng` (6 posts) "  collapsed>


<panel  header="**1. :fas-info-circle: Solved: es/ab3 import error for javafx macOS despite following advisory**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/156" expanded>

Have tried installing javafx macOS as per the [github pages](https://nus-cs2103-ay2324s2.github.io/website/admin/programmingLanguages.html).
However it did not work. Despite deleting everything in the JavaVirtualMachines and the relevant files, javafx still failed to run.

After a while I realised it was because the original java running on my mac was not from Oracle and not kept within Library/Users/Java/JavaVirtualMachines, hence following the youtube video did not really work.

I was able to resolve this issue by removing the OpenJDK following [this](https://admin-api.codejava.net/java-se/uninstall-jdk-on-macos). Where apart from removing the files given in the youtube video, I also ran 

```bash
sudo rm -rf Path/To/OpenJDK
```

After resetting the environment variable of JAVA_HOME to point towards the newly installed azul-11.jdk and restarting the IDE, gradle could finally run with javafx.

Hope this helps other mac users facing this issue!
</panel>

I faced a similar issue before but I'm using windows so not sure if my solution will be helpful. The problem that I faced was I used the wrong jar file association (I was using jre instead of jdk). 

In terminal, I checked for the current jar file association using `ftype | find "jarfile"`. My jar file association was: `jarfile="C:\Program Files\Java\jre-1.8\bin\javaw.exe" -jar "%1" %*`. 

Using the Registry Editor application, I clicked into the following path: `Computer\HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\jarfile\shell\open\command`. 
Then, I updated the jar file association to: `"C:\Program Files\Java\jdk-17.0.5\bin\javaw.exe" -jar "%1" %*`.  Note that your version of jdk and jre may differ slightly so do edit the paths accordingly. 

You may also want to read through these 2 stack overflow discussions ([discussion 1](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/5827164/why-does-my-jar-file-execute-at-cmd-but-not-on-double-click?rq=3), [discussion 2](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/9259389/jar-file-doesnt-open-upon-double-click)) that I referred to for other solutions. 
</panel>

<panel  header="**4 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/147#issuecomment-1919461073" expanded>

OK I figured it out.

Using github desktop,
- Start a branch branch-Level-7. 
- Commit Level 7 implementations to branch-level-7. 
- Switch branch back to master
- In the top toolbar, Branch -&gt; Merge into current branch... -&gt; select branch-level-7 -&gt; create a merge commit
- Add the tags into the master commit
- Push all the branches and tags to origin

</panel>

<panel  header="**4 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/243#issuecomment-1936031234" expanded>

1. Not too sure whether this will fix your issue, but one way you can clean up the patterns array is the split it into two different arrays - one array to store date formats and another array to store time formats. You can then use a nested for-loop and concatenate every single pairing of date and time formats while checking:

```
        String[] possibleDates = ``{``
                "d/M/yyyy",
                "d-M-yyyy",
                "d/M/yy",
                "d-M-yy",
                "dMMyyyy",
                "dMMyy",

                "dd/MM/yyyy",
                "dd-MM-yyyy",
                "yyyy-MM-dd",

                "dd/MM/yy",
                "dd-MM-yy",
                "ddMMyyyy",
                "ddMMyy",``}``;

        String[] possibleTimes = ``{``"HHmm", "HH:mm", "HH", "h:mma",``}``;

        for (String datePattern : possibleDates) ``{``
            for (String timePattern : possibleTimes) ``{``
                //check that time pattern comes before date pattern
                try ``{``
                    DateTimeFormatter formatter = DateTimeFormatter.ofPattern(timePattern + " " + datePattern);
                    return LocalDateTime.parse(input, formatter);
                ``}`` catch (Exception e) ``{``
                    //do nothing
                ``}``
                //check that time pattern comes after date pattern
                try ``{``
                    DateTimeFormatter formatter = DateTimeFormatter.ofPattern(datePattern + " " + timePattern);
                    return LocalDateTime.parse(input, formatter);
                ``}`` catch (Exception e) ``{``
                    //do nothing
                ``}``
            ``}``
        ``}``
```

The formats are clearer this way, and if it is an issue of an invalid datetime format hopefully you can catch it this way.

2. If the above doesn't fix it, maybe you can send the error which you are getting? Will give a better sensing of what is going wrong 


</panel>

<panel  header="**5 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/314#issuecomment-1951655846" expanded>

Personally I used Github Copilot during development of the iP. Here are some of my insights:

GitHub Copilot (GCP)
+ usually accurate for trivial code like printing to console and simple iterations through lists

+ fairly accurate production of javadoc (may need to amend 5-10% of the time)

- tends to produce incorrect code for more complex tasks like sorting on a custom comparator, or loops with more complex iterations

- can easily mislead the programmer to work in the wrong direction (may produce a set of code which looks like it may work at first, but actually costs the programmer to spend 5-10 mins trying to debug it before realising it cannot work)

TLDR: If used efficiently, you can potentially cut your production time by up to 40 or 50%. If used haphazardly, you could end up wasting more time instead debugging code which was poorly-written by GCP. Personally found GCP helping more than it hurt, but need to be conscious of which suggestions you are accepting.
</panel>

</panel>

<panel type="info" header="### 129. TAN ..OVAN `@jovantanyk` (4 posts) <span class=text-warning>:octicon-eye:</span>"  collapsed>


<panel  header="**1 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/31#issuecomment-1903526934" expanded>

There are two types of binding in java, static binding (early binding ) and dynamic binding (late binding). Overriding methods are resolved using dynamic while overloaded methods are resolved using static binding. The main difference between the two is the stage they take place in, static binding takes place during compile time while dynamic binding takes place during runtime. When you overload a method, the compiler is able to tell which method you're trying to call based on the method signature (name + parameter list). When you use method overriding, the compiler doesn't know which method you're trying to call since the method signature is the same in both subclass and superclass. Take this for example

```
    public static class A ``{``
        void print()
        ``{``
            // Line 1
        ``}``
    ``}``
    public static class B extends A ``{``
        @Override void print()
        ``{``
          // Line 2
        ``}``
    ``}``

    public static void main(String[] args)
    ``{``
        A a = new A();
        A b = new B();
        a.print()
        b.print()
   ``}``
```
During compile time objects aren't initialized yet, so when we do b.print() we have no idea which function to call, the one in the subclass or the one in the superclass. It is only after dynamic binding during runtime that we actually know which function to call. Hope this helps
</panel>

Hi Profs and TAs, should the following issue be considered a feature flaw as indicated by the tester?

> The symbol "," might be present in some patients' offical names. Given that the official name should be supplied in a patient management app, disallowing the "," symbol would cause some patients' identification information unable to be inputted into the app.
> 
> Steps to reproduce:

>

According to the FAQ :
> Q5:
> Can we tweak validity checks for a user input, or error/exception handling?
> 
> A:
> Can be allowed only if the current behavior causes the software to misbehave (i.e., crash, give incorrect results, store inconsistent data, or make it unusable for typical users).

This can be considered unusable for typical users as certain user's names are considered invalid when they contain special characters. Thus it is considered a functionality bug if we are fixing to allow for those names.

> @HongRay The grading scripts go by the timestamp of the commit, irrespective of when the commits were merged to the team repo. 
> Suppose you created some commits in week 8 but did not create a PR (because the feature is not complete yet). And in week 9, you added some more commits, and created a PR, which was merged. At that point, the grading scripts will see your commits in the team repo, and will recognize that you committed in week 8 as well as week 9, turning both weeks to green. **A:** Can be allowed only if the current behavior causes the software to misbehave (i.e., crash, **give incorrect results**, store inconsistent data, or make it **unusable for typical users**).

e.g. `addpts n/Alex p/1000`, `addmempts n/James mp/50000`, `additem i/Chocolate p/7000`

However, in v1.3 we did not not put a limit on the number of points. Now, if we add a large but reasonable number of points there is an integer overflow problem and the value becomes negative. Since we are using a `Points` variable, it is very likely that a typical user may input these large values as the `Points` only increases for the person's whole lifetime. Moreover, since all our commands are related, this overflow can result in other functions failing as well.

Hence, we believe it is giving **incorrect results** when we use commands like `addpts` as the value becomes negative after 2,147,483,647.

As such, is this considered a bug and can we restrict the max number of points someone can have for the usability of the app for a typical user?

<panel type="info" header="### 163. JERE..HONG `@jeremiahlzz` (2 posts) "  collapsed>


<panel  header="**1 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/219#issuecomment-1933809684" expanded>

As Prof. has mentioned, exception handling is highly subjective and it is up you (or your team) to decide where to draw the line(s).

For me personally I consider `File Corrupted` and `File Not Found`, exceptions that should be handled in the `Storage` class. It relates to the storage data retrieval and as such, should be handled within and not by the external class utilizing it. This keeps a level of abstraction as external classes do not have to bother handling such trivial cases. Exceptions should be thrown (out of the class) only if the current class is unable to handle the error.

I agree with you in your example with the `DukeException`; if an appropriate exception is already available we should be using it instead of creating custom exceptions. I disagree with @JerryO3 's use (but it's not wrong to do so), as we can easily differentiate where the exception is thrown by simply following the stack-trace. Custom exception classes add a layer of complexity and if not named properly will cause confusion and decrease readability (like your example `DukeException`; what kind of error is it actually? I would not know without looking at code)
</panel>

<panel  header="**2 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/446#issuecomment-1985387795" expanded>

My impression is also that the two are very similar and can sometimes be used interchangeably.


One small difference I can think of is with regards to the type of project you have; **waterfall or agile**:

* In waterfall, you are developing with a clear end in mind. The definition of late and one time is: 

> Late and one-time: wait till all components are completed and integrate all finished components near the end of the project.

which is well representative of waterfall. Thus, `Late and One time / Early and Frequent` would be more applicable.

* In agile, you are iteratively developing, with small goals along the way.  The definition of big bang is:

> Big-bang integration: integrate all components at the same time.

which has no mention of waiting for an `end of project`. We can simply wait for all major components and start integrating only at the end of each sprint. Thus, `Big-bang / Incremental` would be more applicable.
</panel>

</panel>

> Thanks prof! However my java version is 17.. But all the steps about settings in IntelliJ are correct. I re-uploaded the compiled file.

hi, your terminal and IDE can be using different java versions. IDE is an integrated environment and is separate from your terminal, when you do `java -version` it checks your own environment variables which is **separate** from IntelliJ's configuration. So, while you may have ensured that IntelliJ and Gradle is using java 11, if your terminal is detecting java 17, it will not be able to run files compiled using java 11

> @bgopi23 Hmm do you have any idea why it failed... it works fine on my side so I have no clue why the linkage error or your failed run happens :(

when you say "works fine", did you use your terminal to run or you run Launcher.java directly on intelliJ? The latter works because as mentioned earlier, it is an integrated environment. 
If you can run it on your terminal, but other users could not run in on theirs, then it is very likely that you did shadowJar with a different java version

here's a few things to check:
1) run `java -version` in **your terminal**, make sure its java 11
2) check intelliJ's SDK again just to be sure it is also java 11
3) check your fxml files again just in case
4) go to Files > Settings, look for Gradle and check "Gradle JVM", make sure it uses java 11 which should match the project's SDK

hope this helps!
</panel>

</panel>

<panel type="info" header="### 170. TITU.. JUN `@tituschewxj` (2 posts) <span class=text-warning>:octicon-eye:</span>"  collapsed>


<panel  header="**1 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/122#issuecomment-1915896038" expanded>

`nextLine()` throws a `NoSuchElementException` if no line was found. This means that `nextLine()` tries to read the next line from the `input.txt` file, but doesn't find a line.

To fix this, you can add the your command to exit, `bye`, as the last line of your `input.txt` file, so that `nextLine()` isn't called when there is no next line in your `input.txt`.
</panel>

<panel  header="**2 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/242#issuecomment-1948061039" expanded>

I think both approaches are valid, and the better approach would depend on what kind of product and target user you have in mind, as there are tradeoffs between each approach.

For example, if your target user is someone that prefers typing text fast over checking their calendar and inputting a date in the correct format, the first approach may be better, as it allows the user to quickly add tasks.

On the other hand, if your target user prefers the control and functionality over having actual dates, then the second approach may be better.
</panel>

</panel>

<panel  header="**2. :fas-info-circle: Is Implementing an interface really a IS-A relationship?**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/262" expanded>

Week 4 notes suggest that "A class implementing an interface results in an is-a relationship"

> Suppose SalariedStaff is an interface that contains two methods setSalary(int) and getSalary(). AcademicStaff can declare itself as implementing the SalariedStaff interface, which means the AcademicStaff class must implement all the methods specified by the SalariedStaff interface i.e., setSalary(int) and getSalary()

However I would like to propose another example that isn't as clear that 

Suppose IHasAbility is an interface that contains the method useAbility(). A healer is a game character that can declare itself as implementing the IHasAbility interface. Which means the Healer must implement the method useAbility(). Yet However, this doesn't mean a healer IS-A HasAbility. I would like to think of implements as a promise of features rather than a IS-A relationship.

<panel type="info" header="### 186. WU Y..HENG `@jessicawyz` (2 posts) "  collapsed>


<panel  header="**1. :fas-info-circle: Fixing a bug will change our original implementation**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/685" expanded>


Hi Profs and TAs,

We have a bug that is high severity. Tester reported that they can add 2 exams with the same details to the same person but when deleting, they can only delete the first exam and the second exam is null so it cannot be deleted.

This is because current code used 2 data structures to represent the data, ObservableList and HashSet. Thus when duplicate exams are added, it can be added to ObservableList as separate objects but can only be added to HashSet once. Therefore HashSet can only contain unique exams. This caused a discrepancy between the two lists.

Are we allowed to 
(a) change the implementation of exam using HashSet. (Would require a lot of code changes as exam is used in many commands)
(b) change the implementation of ObservableList such that it no longer allow duplicates

Thank you
</panel>

I encountered the same issue before. It could run with Intellj but not with Gradle. So what I do are:

1. Run Gradle clear, then try whether or not it could be run.
2. clear all the current projects, and classes that are shown at the top of the IntelliJ(on the left of the Run button)
3. run the main() method first, after that, if it runs successfully, then run the class.
4. Check your current project environment, whether it is default Java version 11, and Language Level is SDK default.
5. clear the data files(your load and save)
6. make sure the gradle setting is as same as website mentioned.

I am indeed not sure why this happen but these are what I do. The first time after implementing Gradle I had the same issue as you, and it happened several times later. Every time it happens, I just repeat the process. It somehow happened and somehow not. But most of the time run 3 first, and then run the whole class is successful.
</panel>

</panel>

<panel type="info" header="### 208. REGA..N FU `@ReganChoy` (1 posts) "  collapsed>


<panel  header="**1 :fas-comment:**" popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2324S2/forum/issues/148#issuecomment-1921883474" expanded>

From what I understand, distZip and distTar are both from the "distribution" plugin. A new "distribution" directory will be created and the [root_name].jar will be packaged into a zip and tar folder respectively.

dependsOn seems to reinforce an order in executing tasks.
A.dependsOn(B) would mean A can only run if B is done or present. This is different from mustRunAfter where A.mustRunAfter(B).
If both A and B are present, B runs first then A. However, if B is not present, A can still execute.

Do correct me if I am wrong!

Sources:
https://docs.gradle.org/current/userguide/distribution_plugin.html
https://melix.github.io/blog/2021/10/gradle-quickie-dependson.html
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/42033490/whats-the-difference-between-mustrunafter-and-dependson-in-gradle

</panel>

</panel>

Based on the stacktrace you provided, I believe the error is caused by the null value being passed to instantiate a `javafx.scene.image.Image` object that is used in your fxml file. This is likely due to the image not being found on your file system.

If you are following the tutorial from the website, the issue is likely caused by missing profile picture(s) of your toothless chatbot and the user which causes the `getResourceAsStream` method to [return null](https://docs.oracle.com/en%2Fjava%2Fjavase%2F11%2Fdocs%2Fapi%2F%2F/java.base/java/lang/ClassLoader.html#getResourceAsStream(java.lang.String)) as your specified resource(s) are not found.

  `private final Image userImage = new Image(this.getClass().getResourceAsStream("/images/DaUser.png"));`
`private final Image dukeImage = new Image(this.getClass().getResourceAsStream("/images/DaDuke.png"));`

If that is indeed the issue, you may wish to follow my directory structure (referenced from the cs2103t website) which can be found [here ](https://github.com/jjchee77/ip/tree/master/src/main/resources)

It is difficult to pinpoint the exact issue without being able to see your code, but hope this helps.
</panel>

</panel>
